is a village in the Dutch province
. In the Netherlands, it's famous as it is home to a well-known seal rescue centre.
Pieterburen is a good half hour's drive from
, via the N361 and N363. There are also fine road connections to other towns in the region. There's no train station in the village itself. The closest station are in neighbouring

. From there, buses are available. However, unless you're visiting those towns, in the summer months it's probably easier to take a direct bus from Groningen, as special services run from the province capital to the seal rescue centre.
Pieterburen isn't too large. You can get by on foot of bike. If you're here by car, that also works.

value: content=The seal rescue centre is the main attraction in town. It's open daily from 10am to 5pm, has a small visitors centre and of course you can watch any seals that are currently residing there. Obviously, this is a rescue centre, not a zoo, so the number of seals varies.
Go mud walking. Pieterburen is a starting place for guided mud walks on the bottom of the Wadden sea, at low tide.
If you enjoy hiking, set out on the longest Dutch walking route, the "Pieterpad". It starts right here at Pieterburen and runs all the way south to the  Sint-Pietersberg in
